abstracts.cdata!:
This impact evaluation report covers the
            India Tarai Seeds and First Indonesia Seeds projects,
            initiated in 1969 and 1971, respectively. Both projects were
            completed in 1978 and audited by Operations Evaluation
            Department (OED) in 1979. These projects were the first
            Bank-supported seed projects and are the first to be the
            subject of an impact evaluation. The main objective in both
            projects was to stimulate food grain production by improving
            seed availability of the new high yielding varieties (HYV).
            The Impact Study finds that, on balance, both projects have
            been successful in achieving their broad objectives,
            although adequate data are not available to confirm or
            reject the rate of return estimates of the appraisals and
            the Project Performance Appraisal Repot (PCRs). Important
            lessons learned from these projects are as follows: (i)
            Initial demand for certified seed depends primarily on a
            source of new already proven high yielding germ plasm. In
            these projects, the plant breeding research of International
            Center for Maize and Wheat Improvement (CIMMYT) on wheat and
            International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) on rice, and
            their continued cooperation with national institutions, was
            a key element in justifying the expansion of processing
            capacity for the seed industry. However, the lack of
            outstanding new HYV in recent years has constrained the
            demand for certified seed. (ii) Surges in seed demand may
            occur from time to time as the result of a build-up of
            damaging insects or disease organisms such as occurred in
            Indonesia with Brown Plant Hopper (BPH) and the virus
            diseases for which it is the vector. Over time, a series of
            varieties with improved genetic resistance have been bred
            and released to seed producers, and these have provided a
            series of demand surges for processed seed.
